turns.speaker: user
turns.utterance: I'm calling about a car insurance claim. My car was damaged in a hit-and-run last week, claim number is 2023-10-27-458.

turns.speaker: agent
turns.utterance: Thank you for calling. I have located claim 2023-10-27-458. I see it's for a hit-and-run incident. Can you confirm your name and date of birth for verification?

turns.speaker: user
turns.utterance: Yes, it's Jane Doe, born January 15, 1988. I've already submitted all the police reports and photos. What's the hold-up? It's been over a week!

turns.speaker: agent
turns.utterance: Thank you, Ms. Doe. I understand your frustration. The claim is currently under review. We are waiting for an estimate from the mechanic you selected. Once we receive that, we can proceed with the assessment. Have you by any chance already provided us the estimate?

turns.speaker: user
turns.utterance: I believe I gave you the name and contact information of the auto repair shop. Shouldn't you be getting that from them directly? What am I paying insurance for if I have to chase down the estimate myself?

turns.speaker: agent
turns.utterance: You are absolutely right, Ms. Doe. Our standard procedure is to obtain the estimate directly from the shop. I apologize for any inconvenience. I will send a request to the auto repair shop immediately for the estimate and update the claim file. I will email you once I receive it, is the email on file still jane.doe@example.com?

turns.speaker: user
turns.utterance: Yes, that's the correct email. Thanks, I appreciate you looking into this. But what if the other driver is never found? How does that affect my deductible or my rates?
